awd_titl_txt: The Role of Mating System Divergence in Plant Speciation
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the formation of new species, the process of speciation, is among the most challenging problems in evolutionary biology. Rates of speciation vary widely among flowering plants and are strongly associated with the degree of reproduction via self-fertilization versus mating with other individuals (known as the plant 'mating system'). This project integrates new evolutionary theory, field and laboratory experiments, and genomic analyses to test key hypotheses about the role of mating system changes in plant speciation. The project investigates the processes that determine where and when strong barriers to mating occur. It will clarify whether evolutionary changes in rates of self-fertilization directly promote reproductive isolation between diverging species. The experimental work focuses on two subspecies of the California annual plant, Clarkia xantiana, which differ in mating system. One subspecies is primarily self-fertilizing the other is primarily outcrossing. These plants are ideal for study because they exhibit features of newly formed species. However, they have only recently diverged and can still interbreed. Moreover, their flowers are substantially different where they co-occur, a signature of the speciation process. The proposed work will also involve extensive outreach to the public via an innovative program called, 'Market Science', where researchers present topics to and engage directly with the public at local farmers' markets. This highly successful program will be expanded to include new topics on evolutionary biology. The proposed project will also directly involve undergraduates in authentic research in the classroom.

The proposed work address three primary objectives. Aim 1 examines the role of natural selection in the evolution of reproductive character displacement between sister outcrossing and selfing lineages. This work involves the development of novel theoretical models of character displacement that incorporate divergence in mating system. It also involves large-scale field experiments that quantify the role of individual traits in conferring reproductive isolation and determine their genetic basis. Aim 2 examines the ecological and genetic costs of hybrid formation between sister outcrossing and selfing lineages. This work involves field experiments and genomic analyses that quantify the reproductive fitness of hybrids. Aim 3 synthesizes Aims 1 and 2 by asking about how reproductive isolating mechanisms collectively influence genome-wide patterns of variation and introgression between the two taxa. This integrative work will advance evolutionary research by calling attention to the potential for mating system to influence speciation broadly in nature.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit
Our project examined the role of plant mating system divergence - the evolution of self-fertilization from cross-fertilization - in the formation of new plant species. We focused on recently diverged Clarkia species that differ in mating system and are in secondary contact. Two of the main goals were to: (1) quantify the degree of admixture (exchange of genetic variants) between two focal taxa and understand the factors that determine the degree of admixture, and (2) test the hypothesis that natural selection has strengthened barriers to genetic exchange where the two taxa overlap in distribution and identify traits that are the targets of this natural selection. 

We found that admixture varies substantially among geographic locations where the two taxa contact one another. This variation in admixture is predicted strongly by climate variation, which modulates the strength of barriers that influence the formation of hybrids (premating). Admixture is also strongly asymmetric between taxa, with greater genetic exchange occurring from the self-fertiizing taxon to the cross-fertilizing taxon. Although admixture is apparent in most places where the two taxa encounter one another, we find no evidence of first or early generation hybrids. 

Our experimental work focused on understanding why hybrids form so rarely in the field even though the two taxa are cross compatible and occur physically close to one another. We developed set of genetic lines of the self-fertilzing taxon that were created by crosses (recombinant inbred lines) such that they contained a large amount of trait variation in flowers. We exposed them to the cross-fertilizing taxon in natural environments in an effort to understand which floral traits most strongly prevent versus facilitate hybridization. Our results show that only petal size modulates hybridization. Importantly, this is also the only trait that exhibits character displacement - petal size differs more between the two taxa where their geographic ranges overlap than where they occur separately. This is unusually strong evidence for reinforcement, the idea that natural selection strengthens barriers to hybridization where two diverging taxa co-occur. 

Broader Impacts
The PIs both integrated the project research into their primary undergraduate courses. Braindvain used datasets from the project in his Biostatistics course. As part of this instruction, students learned concepts related to speciation, hybridization, and floral evolution. Moeller developed new modules for his course on plant evolution and diversity that used components of this project to illustrate concepts in plant evolution. 

The research team particpated extensively in education outreach involving K-12 students. In one effort, team members engaged with students in classrooms across the United States to discuss careers in scientific research and to discuss their research as part of this project. Team members also mentored students online who were conducting plant research projects. Last, they mentored undergraduates at the Universtiy of Minnesota who were seeking research opportunities and exploring options for careers. 

The project involved many undergraduates in research in the field and laboratory. These students received mentorship related to their understanding of key evolutionary concepts and related to the execution of specific research approaches. The project supported one REU student who assisted with field experiments and developed their own independent project. The project supported two PhD students (one woman) who have interests in careers in academics. The project supported their training in field experimentation and the use of population genomic tools. The project supported two postdocs (both women), who have obtained tenure track faculty positions at R1 institutions (U. Chicago, U. Texas-Austin).
